story.full_text:
For Thanksgiving, try this game.
Find the guilty turkey's name in a mystery story rhyme
telling of the strangest crime. Though in winter, skies are grey, 
sunshine brightly shone today, shimmering on a thousand lakes
when America awakes. Autumn winds in mornings cold
paint the leaves of trees bright gold! One lone farmer in his field
studied all the food revealed. With no children, all alone,
he lived where the food was grown. In the back, a wondrous spread
where Thanksgiving turkey’s bred. His calendar showed the dates
America celebrates. And this morning it would say
he'd awoken to Thanksgiving day! Through the country, he now knew, 
they'd enjoy the food he grew. Favorite dishes people loved 
onto dinner plates were shoved. Family dinner tables shone
with the tasty plants he'd grown. Parents, children, all await it.
All but one group: Turkeys hate it. In America, each year
turkeys dread this day with fear, fearing folks on every street
hungering for turkey meat. When the daylight brightly broke,
all the farmer's birds awoke. Since it is a holiday,
all turkeys can talk today in a wide and special space, 
glowing bright with autumn’s grace. In the farmer's gloomy pen,
Rusty checked the day again. Sure today he'd meet his fate:
someone else's dinner plate. Gobbling to all who'd listen,
"With salt brine I soon will glisten." Rusty's worried eyes would droop,
sadly in a shadowed coop. Rusty's brother, Tiny, giggled,
and his loose red wattle wiggled on his beak, as he did say,
"Strange to fear a holiday. You greet it with such suspicion.
I think that's just superstition. Any day could be your last.
Learn to live your life out fast! Any day — and, please remember, 
no more likely in November." But Rusty was not placated,
filled with dread and gloom he waited. His sad beak would not be brightened,
it's sharp point looked dull and frightened. "In our turkey pen we lie;
on the fourth Thursday, we die." Though his brother just adored him,
other turkeys just ignored him. There were two more playing games,
Tom and Libby were their names. Strutting 'round the turkey pen,
Tom tried to impress the hen, fanning his best turkey feather,
hoping they'd soon be together. Tom arrived three days before
and bragged of a far-off shore where the farmers knew their worth,
letting turkeys roam the earth. "Happy turkeys live there still,
on the shores of Turkeyville." Though the turkeys liked his joke,
one shy Turkey never spoke. Libby was her name — quite cute
but they worried she was mute. Libby seemed to like their den, 
she never left the turkey pen. Even when the bright sun shone,
Libby wouldn't leave alone. Rusty searched in vain for hope.
"Maybe it's still Wednesday. Nope." Tiny laughed and teased poor Rusty.
"Don't you think our farmer's trusty? I think you should just relax.
Just forget the farmer's axe." Tom gave his strong wings a flap.
Libby yawned, and took a nap. All their gobbling gabbing sounds
filled the farmer's fertile grounds. Soon the farmer had returned
for a dinner that he'd earned. Standing in the wintry sun,
his hard work was finally done. He'd prepare a pumpkin pie,
mashed potatoes, piled high. His best plate would be deserving
for the meal he'd be serving. Now was time to pick the winner — 
which turkey to choose for dinner? He strolled proud into his yard,
studying his pen quite hard. Soon the farmer leaned in to stare
at the turkeys waiting there. Rusty shook with fear and dread.		
Tiny laughed and bobbed his head. Libby's sleepy eyes were shutting.
Tom ignored them all, still strutting. In November, nature lies
under dreary winter skies. Autumn touched the meadows too,
where the yellow wheat stalks grew. Soon the farmer looked around
but no sharp axe could be found. Then he looked around again,
Ten feet from the turkey pen. What he saw would make him smile:
sawdust in a messy pile. where his axe had laid
now was just a lonely blade but no handle that could bring it
to the farmer's arms to swing it. It was gone, the farmer knew,
thanks to one smart turkey who wishing that the axe was banished,
pecked its handle till it vanished! It would take at least a week
to destroy it with a beak. Now the farmer, laughing, said
to the turkeys by his shed: "Was my turkey-keeping lax?
Which of you destroyed my axe?" For Thanksgiving, try this game.
Find the guilty turkey's name!

Please analyze all the clues and evidence presented in the story and identify who the culprit is. Explain your reasoning step by step, considering:
1. The motives of different characters
2. The opportunities each character had
3. Any physical evidence or alibis
4. The logical deduction from the clues presented

<THOUGHT PROCESS>
<thought process here>
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

Who are the possible suspects? List them here:

<SUSPECTS>
<names(s) for all suspects here, comma separated>
</SUSPECTS>

Who is the culprit (or culprits, if more than one) and why? I want you to distinguish between the main culprit(s) and the accomplices (if any). If there are none, write None. If possible, include first and last names, as well as any aliases. Answer in the form:

<name(s) here>
</MAIN CULPRIT(S)>

<ACCOMPLICE(S)>
<name(s) here>
</ACCOMPLICE(S)>

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1.  Motive  
   •  All turkeys would prefer that no axe be available, but Rusty alone openly dreads Thanksgiving, repeats “on the fourth Thursday, we die,” and talks of being on someone’s plate.  
   •  Tiny thinks the danger is “just superstition” and laughs at Rusty – he has no sense of urgency.  
   •  Tom boasts that in “Turkeyville” no-one eats turkeys; he sees himself as too important to be killed and is busy impressing Libby.  
   •  Libby seems passive, sleepy, and shows no concern at all.

2.  Opportunity and time requirement  
   •  The handle was steadily reduced to sawdust.  The rhyme even says: “It would take at least a week / to destroy it with a beak.”  
   •  Therefore the guilty turkey had to be in the yard for a week or more.  
        –  Tom “arrived three days before” – three days is not enough.  
        –  Tiny and Rusty have lived there long-term; so could Libby.  
   •  Physical access: the axe lay ten feet from the pen.  A turkey that “never left the turkey pen” (Libby) would not reach it.  The culprit must have been willing to slip outside when the farmer was absent.  Rusty is the only bird shown actually looking out of the pen each dawn, checking the calendar and fretting; he was clearly watching the yard.

3.  Behavioural clues  
   •  Rusty is the sole turkey portrayed as actively searching for a way to survive; fear is a strong motivator to work patiently night after night.  
   •  Tiny’s ridicule, Tom’s vanity, and Libby’s lethargy make it unlikely any of them would spend hours gnawing wood.  
   •  The poem’s narrator twice draws special attention to Rusty just before and after the axe discovery – a literary spotlight.

4.  Logical deduction  
   •  Only a turkey with (i) a strong motive, (ii) at least a week of free time, and (iii) willingness/ability to leave the pen, could finish the job.  
   •  That description fits Rusty alone.  Therefore Rusty is the culprit.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Rusty, Tiny, Tom, Libby
</SUSPECTS>

<MAIN CULPRIT(S)>
Rusty
</MAIN CULPRIT(S)>

<ACCOMPLICE(S)>
None
</ACCOMPLICE(S)>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
A week or more before Thanksgiving, Rusty began to act on his dread.  
Each night, when the farmer went inside, Rusty squeezed through a gap in the pen or hopped the low fence, waddled the ten feet to the chopping block, and pecked industriously at the axe-handle.  He worked until his beak ached, then crept back before dawn so no one (not even the other turkeys) noticed.  By Thanksgiving morning the wooden handle had been reduced to splinters and sawdust, leaving only the metal blade.  When the farmer came to choose his bird he found the useless blade and realised someone—some turkey—had sabotaged it.  Rusty, badly frightened but now secretly triumphant, had saved his own neck (and, for the moment, everybody else’s) by destroying the axe.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
Tiny had time and access, but no motive; he mocked Rusty’s fear and called it “superstition,” so he would not spend a week of effort on a danger he did not believe in.  
Tom arrived only “three days before,” far less than the week the poem says was needed to chew through the handle.  He could not have finished the job in time.  
Libby “never left the turkey pen”… and the axe was ten feet outside it.  Unless the poem is lying about her never leaving, she lacked physical opportunity.  Furthermore, her sleepy, indifferent disposition provides no evident motive.  
Thus only Rusty matches all the required conditions, proving the other turkeys innocent.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>

original_metadata.reveal_text:
"Though the guilty one would hide
they'll soon be identified,"
said the farmer with a grin,
calling his four turkeys in.
He'd brought great anticipation
to the turkey congregation.
With a smile he would use
logic to reveal the clues.
"Libby, you're a turkey who
I am not expecting to
peck and peck and peck again.
You're to shy to leave the pen!
Tiny -- in the pen you stayed
just because you're not afraid.
In you I see one big quirk:
too carefree for that much work!
Tom, I know that it's not you.
You've been here three days — you're too new!
It would take at least a week.
to destroy that with your beak."
Rusty knew his time had come.
His thin turkey legs felt numb.
"Rusty, now I'm on a roll.
I noticed your beak was dull
like a turkey who's been pecking
while the date he kept re-checking."
Rusty sighed and said, "It's true.
What else was there I could do?"
Then the farmer laughed and said,
"What goes through your turkey head?
Look at you, already beaten,
so convinced that you'll be eaten.
When I came to pick the winner —
one turkey to have for dinner —
I just meant that you're invited
to my table – I'm delighted!
Yes, for dinner. I'll prepare it.
I just want someone to share it!
I want just to feed you, only.
As a farmer — I get lonely.
For dinner, there are turkeys, true —
But I'll serve tasty foods to you!"
As an early autumn moon
shimmered in the afternoon,
he heard turkeys laugh and squall,
and Rusty laughed the most of all.
